subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Updated keyboard mappings, and examples for Out and Ooze
msgSnippet: Hi Moira, Could you please update your chart for the QS-Nu assignments for #10 and #39? I swapped them yesterday, so those rows can now be labeled as
messageBody:
Hi Moira,

Could you please update your chart for the QS-Nu assignments for #10
and #39? I swapped them yesterday, so those rows can now be labeled as
agreements. We also now have agreement for #40, and the naming dot.

Thanks.

Ted


On Jan 9, 2008 9:06 AM, Moira O'Brien <mj@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> I have updated my spreadsheet with the #37/#40 swap agreed by Benct.
>
> I have also included the conversion to the scripts that Ted was quoting
> which will update when changes are made. Is there any other script that
> people would like to see comparisons of?
>
> Moira
>
>
>
> On 09/01/2008, Benct Philip Jonsson <bpj@...> wrote:
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> > Ted Larson Freeman wrote:
> > > Comments:
> > > 1) I think I like Q for #37 after looking at the mappings
> > > of the first sentence...
> >
> > How on earth, then are you going to write #33 and #35? IMHO
> > the only extenuating circumstances for using Q and q for
> > vowels at all are that Q looks similar to O in {nQrT} and q
> > looks similar to oy in {bq, dustrq}. Believe me, I don't
> > really like at all to map QS vowel letters to ASCII
> > consonant letters!
> >
> > > 2) I don't like B for #40 at all. Please, Benct, let's
> > > revert that one.
> > >
> > > I may to try to talk you out of this one. As I said
> > > earlier, I'd really like to see U remain assigned to #40.
> > > This is a pure vowel, a monophthong. B just doesn't work
> > > for it, I think. Meanwhile, #37 is a diphthong, and we
> > > can't expect to have such good assignments for those.
> >
> > OK, you have re-swayed me: #40 shall be U and #37 shall be B
> > in BPJ2, and it's finally proven: I do know more ancient
> > languages than what is good for me! :-)
> >
> > BTW I think I'll rename BPJ2 to QS-B.
> >
> > > Have you given any thought to swapping #43 and #44?
> >
> > It *does* make sense to map the uppercase X to the tall QS
> > letter, so I'll do it!
> >
> > BTW do you have any idea of the text frequency of such pairs
> > as alt-#36 vs. #15 and #39 vs. #10? I dare guess that given
> > the high frequency of /@l/ and /@m/ alt-#36 is more frequent
> > than #15, and on those grounds it is right to map alt-#36 to
> > lowercase c and #15 to uppercase C, but given that all of
> > the words _to, could, should, would are_ abbreviated to
> > spellings not including #39 the text frequency of #39
> > becomes rather low -- as always with reservations for words
> > containing it which are important in a particular text or a
> > particular field --, so that #10 is the more frequent of the
> > two and should be assigned to the lowercase v. Too bad there
> > is no TO graphy which consistently corresponds to #39, or a
> > text frequency comparison would be easy to do!
> >
> > /BP 8^)>
> > --
> > Benct Philip Jonsson -- melroch atte melroch dotte se
> > ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
> > No man forgets his original trade: the rights of
> > nations and of kings sink into questions of grammar,
> > if grammarians discuss them.
> > -Dr. Samuel Johnson (1707 - 1784)
> >
> >
>
>
>
